sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables you to search for files on your system. You can use &app; to perform the following types of search:

listitem.para: Simple search. To use the simple search option, you can type a full filename or a partial filename with wildcards.
Advanced search. To use the advanced search options, you select additional search criteria that you want &app; to apply.

sect1.para: &app; uses the find, grep, and locate UNIX commands.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Search for Files.
Type gnome-search-tool, then press Return.

sect1.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, Simple and Advanced tabbed sections.

sect2.title: To Perform a Simple Search
sect2.para: Use the Simple tabbed section to perform a simple search.
To search for a file on the system, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the Starting in folder field enter the path to the directory in which you want &app; to begin the search. &app; searches in the directory that you specify and the subdirectories of the directory.
In the Find files named field, enter one of the following strings:
A full filename, for example myfile.txt. &app; searches for all files on the system named myfile.txt.
A partial filename, for example gnome. &app; searches for all files on the system that contain the string gnome in their directory path or filename.
A directory path combined with wildcards (*), for example /home/username/*.txt. &app; searches the directory /home/username for all files with the extension .txt.

Click Find to perform the search. &app; displays the results of the search in the Search Results list box. If &app; does not find any files that match the search criteria, the application does not display anything in the Search Results list box.
To open a file displayed in the Search Results list box, double-click on the file. The file opens in your file manager.

sect2.title: To Perform an Advanced Search
sect2.para: Use the Advanced tabbed section to perform an advanced search.
To search for a file on the system, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: In the Starting in folder field, enter the path to the directory in which you want &app; to begin the search. For example, if you enter /home/username/work, &app; begins the search in the work subdirectory and searches in all subdirectories of work. By default, &app; begins the search in the current working directory.
Select the search criteria that you want to apply, as follows:
Click the Add Rule drop-down list box.
Select the search rule that you want to apply.
Click Add to add the search rule to the list of search rules.
Ensure that the Enable check box is selected.
Specify the required search information for the search rule, see for information.
Repeat the above steps for each search rule that you want to apply.
To disable a search rule, deselect the Enable check box next to the rule. To remove a search rule from the Rules list, select the rule, then click Remove.

Click Find to perform the search. &app; displays the results of the search in the Search Results list box. If &app; does not find any files that match the search criteria, the application does not display anything in the Search Results list box.
To open a file displayed in the Search Results list box, double-click on the file. The file opens in your file manager.

entry.para: Search for a file by filename. Enter a full filename or a partial filename with wildcards in the field provided. Use * to indicate a sequence of characters. Use ? to indicate a single character. The search is case sensitive.

Search for files that do not match the filename that you enter. Enter a full filename or a partial filename with wildcards in the field provided. Use * to indicate a sequence of characters. Use ? to indicate a single character. The search is case sensitive.
Search only the subdirectories that are mounted on the same disk as the start directory.
Follow symbolic links when searching for files.
Search the directories in ascending order, starting with the lowest directories in the directory hierarchy.
Search for files that are owned by the user specified. Type the name of the user in the text box provided
Search for files that are owned by the group specified. Type the name of the group in the text box provided.
Search for files that are owned by a user or group that is unknown to the system.

Search for files that were modified within the number of days specified. Type the number of days in the text box provided. For example, type 3 to search for files that were modified in the last three days.
Search for files that contain the specified regular expression in their directory path or filename. Type the regular expression in the text box provided.

sect2.title: To Stop a Search
sect2.para: Click Stop to stop a search before &app; completes the search.

sect2.title: To View the Search Command Used by &app;
sect2.para:
To view the command that &app; used to perform the previous search, choose
Search Show Command . The Search Command Line displays the command.

sect2.title: To Save the Search Results
sect2.para:
To save the results of the last search that &app; performed, choose
Search Save Results As . Enter the name of the file to which you want to save the results, then click OK.
